column3: When I arrived at the office, at the time scheduled for me, there were more than 10 people still waiting to be seen! So I asked the secretary to cancel my appointment! How could I serve all those people in such a short time, it was already 3:30 pm! I thought it was disrespectful to schedule so many patients at the same time! And such a delay in responding! How long would each consultation last? It was disappointing to have to give up, time, traffic, paid parking, and having to leave!
column7: Key_Issues_Patient_Experience_Expert:; Overbooking leading to long wait times; Lack of consideration for patients' time and resources
column11: The patient expresses feelings of frustration, anger, and disappointment due to the disrespectful treatment caused by the overbooked appointment and delayed service.  They also feel a sense of waste and loss of time and resources invested in the trip to the office.
column12: To address these negative emotions, validate the patient's feelings by acknowledging their frustration and validating that it is reasonable to feel upset about the situation.
column13: Suggested_Approach_Clinical_Psychologist:; Emphasize understanding and apologize for the inconvenience caused.; Guide them through relaxation techniques to manage anger and frustration in the moment.; Explore coping mechanisms to deal with similar situations in the future, such as proactive communication with the office or exploring alternative providers.
column15: Issues_Identified_Communication_Expert:; Overbooking of appointments leading to significant wait times.; Lack of timely communication regarding potential delays.; Implement a system to prevent overbooking and ensure realistic appointment scheduling.; Establish clear communication protocols for informing patients of potential delays or changes in appointment times.
column17: The clinic should prioritize patient experience by improving their appointment scheduling and communication practices to minimize wait times and ensure timely updates to patients.
column18: Key_Issues_Manager_and_Advisor:; Overbooking of appointments resulting in prolonged waiting times.; Inadequate communication regarding appointment delays or changes.; Implement an appointment scheduling system that prevents overbooking and ensures realistic time allocations for each patient.; Establish clear protocols for proactively communicating potential delays or modifications to patients' scheduled appointment times.

column3: By far the worst medical care I've had in my life. I was treated with complete indifference. I arrived ahead of schedule, but I saw the Dr leave upon my arrival to deal with personal matters. More than half an hour later he returned to my appointment, in which he must not have spoken 5 words. The consultation itself didn't last 1 minute. The doctor interrupted me while I was speaking, or rather, trying to explain what I was feeling. Even before finishing, he gave me an ineligible prescription without explaining what it was, without saying what it could be, or what I felt could be X or Y, etc... he ordered an exam (ineligible) and then look for a hospital. Hey!?! If your health plan, like mine, has scheduled an appointment with this doctor, my suggestion is that you look for another one immediately.
column7: Key_Issues_Patient_Experience_Expert:; Doctor's indifference and rude behavior, including leaving during the appointment and interrupting the patient.; Lack of communication regarding prescriptions and further examinations ordered by the doctor.
column11: The patient expresses feelings of anger, frustration,  disrespect, and helplessness. They likely feel unheard, invalidated, and abandoned by the healthcare system. Their use of strong language ("by far the worst," "indifference," "ineligible") indicates a high level of distress and dissatisfaction.
column12: Validation, empathy building, and coping mechanism development are crucial. The patient needs to feel heard and understood.  We should work together to explore their feelings surrounding this experience and help them develop healthy coping mechanisms for managing anger and frustration in future healthcare encounters.
column13: Suggested_Approach_Clinical_Psychologist:; Begin by actively listening to the patient's detailed account of their experience, validating their feelings without judgment.; Explore how this negative encounter has impacted their sense of trust in healthcare providers and their overall well-being.; Help them identify specific triggers that contribute to their anger and frustration in healthcare settings.; Teach coping strategies such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness techniques, or assertive communication skills to manage emotions during future appointments.
column15: Issues_Identified_Communication_Expert:; Lack of attentiveness and respect towards the patient.; Inadequate communication and explanation regarding diagnosis, treatment plan, and prescription.; Implement active listening techniques to ensure patients feel heard and understood.; Provide clear and concise explanations about diagnoses, treatments, and prescriptions.
column17: Healthcare providers should prioritize patient communication by actively listening, explaining procedures clearly, and ensuring patients feel comfortable asking questions.
column18: Key_Issues_Manager_and_Advisor:; Lack of attentiveness and respect towards the patient; Inadequate communication regarding diagnosis, treatment plan, prescription, and follow-up instructions; Implement active listening techniques to ensure patients feel heard and understood; Provide clear explanations about diagnoses, treatments, prescriptions, and follow-up procedures
